Plautus und his audienoo. Plautus' early connexion with the stage gave him the experience requisite for writing a good acting play. We see it in the broad humour of the dialogues, in the variety of the action, and in the dramatic character ol the situations. And, besides, he knew well for whom he was writing; and his audience was not ol a high class. The greater the extravagance, the more amusement it gave; and it is to the knowledge of this that we must attribute the productiori of part os the fourth act of the Tnitummus. We can imagine how the excitable spectators screamed with laughter when the Syco- phant calmly declared that Arabia was in Pontus, and how eagerly they waited to see if his effrontery would support him in declaring that he had positively been introduced to Jove.
